and 10(2)(e), where, in relation to a relevant dwelling in respect of which a 
confirmation of grant approval has been issued under Regulation 9 or in respect

concrete blocks in its construction, that eligible applicant or individual, as the 
case may be, shall give notice in writing to the relevant local authority of the 
payment and the amount thereof within 28 days of the making of that payment. 

(2) On receipt of a notice under paragraph (1), where a payment has 
previously been made under these Regulations to the eligible applicant or

(4) If the eligible applicant or individual concerned, as the case may be, 
does not pay the amount referred to in paragraph (3) within 21 days of receipt

to refuse to make any further payment under these Regulations in respect of the

(5) Any amount not paid to the relevant local authority under paragraph (3)

Answer:
If an eligible applicant later receives a payment outside this scheme for the same damage, they have notification and repayment obligations to the local authority. 

The applicant must give notice in writing to the relevant local authority of the payment and the amount thereof within 28 days of the making of that payment. 

Upon receipt of this notice, the local authority will give notice in writing to the applicant of the total amount paid under these Regulations to the applicant. 

The applicant will then be immediately liable to pay to the local authority the lesser of the following amounts:

- The amount equal to the payment or payments made under these Regulations as set out in the notice referred to in paragraph (2), or
- The amount equal to the payment referred to in paragraph (1).

If the applicant does not pay this amount within 21 days of receipt of the notice, the local authority is entitled to refuse to make any further payment under these Regulations in respect of the relevant dwelling concerned. Any amount not paid to the local authority under paragraph (3) shall be recoverable by the local authority as a simple contract debt in a court of competent jurisdiction.

;”.
Answer:
Based on the provided passages, it appears that there are multiple amendments to the European Communities (Vegetable Seeds) Regulations 2001 (S.I. No. 306 of 2001) regarding the definition of "Directive".

Initially, the definition of "Directive" was amended by the European Communities (Vegetable Seeds) (Amendment) Regulations 2020 (S.I. No. 160 of 2020) to include Commission Implementing Directive (EU) 2020/432 of 23 March 2020.

However, subsequent amendments to the definition of "Directive" were made by the European Communities (Vegetable Seeds) (Amendment) Regulations 2020 (S.I. No. 58 of 2020), which removed Commission Implementing Directive (EU) 2020/432 of 23 March 2020 from the definition, and by the European Communities (Vegetable Seeds) (Amendment) (No. 3) Regulations 2020 (S.I. No. 202 of 2020), which added Commission Implementing Directive (EU) 2020/177 of 11 February 2020 and Commission Implementing Directive (EU) 2024/3010 of 29th November 2024 to the definition.

Therefore, the most recent amendment to the definition of "Directive" under the European Communities (Vegetable Seeds) Regulations 2001 (S.I. No. 306 of 2001) is as follows:

The definition of "Directive" means Council Directive 2002/55/EC of 13 June 2002, Council Directive 2003/61/EC of 18 June 2003, Regulation (EC) No 1829/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 September 2003, Council Directive 2004/117/EC of 22 December 2004, Commission Directive 2016/124/EC of 5 December 2006, Commission Directive 2009/74/EC of 26 June 2009, Commission Implementing Directive 2013/45/EU of 7 August 2013, Commission Implementing Directive (EU) 2016/317 of 3 March 2016, Commission Implementing Directive (EU) 2020/177 of 11 February 2020, Commission Implementing Directive (EU) 2020/432 of 23 March 2020, and Commission Implementing Directive (EU) 2024/3010 of 29th November 2024.

However, it appears that the passage for S.I. No. 160 of 2020 is the most relevant to the question, and it updates the definition of "Directive" to include Commission Implementing Directive (EU) 2020/432 of 23 March 2020.

Therefore, the answer to the question is:

S.I. No. 160 of 2020 updated the definition of "Directive" under the European Communities (Vegetable Seeds) Regulations 2001 (S.I. No. 306 of 2001) to include Commission Implementing Directive (EU) 2020/432 of 23 March 2020.

Matters relating to points assigned
Answer:
To answer the question, the procedures that the Sea-Fisheries Protection Authority (SFPA) must follow when an official detects a serious infringement by an Irish or foreign fishing vessel are as follows:

1. **Preparation of a report**: The official must prepare a report and forward it to the SFPA (Regulation 6(1)).
2. **Notification to the SFPA**: The SFPA shall send the report and any material collected to the Determination Panel to determine if a serious infringement has occurred (Regulation 6(2)).
3. **Notification to the licence holder**: The SFPA shall notify the licence holder of the alleged serious infringement, the opportunity to make submissions in writing to the Determination Panel, and the right to request an oral hearing (Regulation 6(6)).
4. **Submission of evidence**: The licence holder shall be given the opportunity to make submissions in writing to the Determination Panel within 30 working days from the date of notification (Regulation 6(5)).
5. **Determination by the Determination Panel**: The Determination Panel shall determine on the balance of probabilities if a serious infringement has occurred within 70 working days of the date of notification (Regulation 6(9)).
6. **Notification of determination**: The Determination Panel shall communicate their determination and reasons for their determination to the SFPA and the licence holder (Regulation 6(11)).
7. **Assignment of points**: If the Determination Panel determines that a serious infringement has occurred, the SFPA shall propose to assign the appropriate points in accordance with Annex XXX of the Commission Regulation (Regulation 7(1)).
8. **Notification of points**: The SFPA shall notify the licence holder of the proposed points and the reasons for the determination (Regulation 7(2)).
9. **Assignment of points**: The assignment of points shall not occur until the period allowed for an appeal under Regulation 12 has expired, without such an appeal having been made, or the determination by the Determination Panel has been upheld by the Appeals Officer (Regulation 7(3)).

These procedures ensure that the SFPA follows a fair and transparent process when detecting serious infringements by Irish or foreign fishing vessels.

According to Regulation 7(3) of the statutory instrument, the assignment of points or the notification to the competent authority of a flag Member State shall not occur until:

(a) the period allowed for an appeal under Regulation 12 has expired without such an appeal having been made, or
(b) where an appeal under Regulation 12 is made, the withdrawal of the appeal or the decision of the Appeals Officer to uphold the determination of the Determination Panel.

In other words, the Appeals Officer can confirm that points should be assigned to a licence holder for a serious infringement only after the appeal period has expired or after the Appeals Officer has made a decision on the appeal.

Therefore, the correct answer is:

The Appeals Officer can confirm that points should be assigned to a licence holder for a serious infringement after the appeal period has expired or after the Appeals Officer has made a decision on the appeal, in accordance with Regulation 7(3) of the statutory instrument.

Answer:
Based on the provided passages, the functions and associated administrative responsibilities transferred from the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection to the Minister for Business, Enterprise and Innovation under this Order are:

- The functions vested in the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection by or under the Acts specified in Part 1 of the Schedule and the provisions of the Acts specified in Part 2 of the Schedule.
- The functions vested in the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection under the Regulations specified in Part 3 of the Schedule.

These functions include all property, rights, and liabilities held, enjoyed, or incurred by the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection in connection with these functions, which are transferred to the Minister for Business, Enterprise and Innovation.

Additionally, the Minister for Business, Enterprise and Innovation is authorized to carry on or complete any matters commenced before the commencement of this Order by or under the authority of the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection, in so far as they relate to the transferred functions.

Therefore, the functions and associated administrative responsibilities transferred from the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection to the Minister for Business, Enterprise and Innovation under this Order include:

- The functions vested in the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection by or under the Acts specified in Part 1 of the Schedule and the provisions of the Acts specified in Part 2 of the Schedule (S.I. No. 438 of 2023).
- The functions vested in the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection under the Regulations specified in Part 3 of the Schedule (S.I. No. 438 of 2023).
- All property, rights, and liabilities held, enjoyed, or incurred by the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection in connection with these functions.
- The authority to carry on or complete any matters commenced before the commencement of this Order by or under the authority of the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection.

These Regulations provide for the payment of a bonus to recipients of social 
welfare payments and to recipients of domiciliary care allowance during the 
month of December 2020. 

The amount of the bonus in the case of recipients of social welfare payments is 
100% of the normal weekly payment payable during the first week in December 
2020, subject to a minimum payment of €20. In the case of domiciliary care 
allowance, the amount of the bonus is 100% of the weekly equivalent of the 
amount of domiciliary care allowance payable during December 2020, subject 
to a minimum payment of €20.

However, there is no specific passage that directly answers this question. Instead, the passages provide information about the bonus payments for different social welfare payments in various years (2020, 2021, 2022, and 2023). 

From the passages, we can infer that the bonus payment applies to recipients of long-term social welfare payments, but the specific circumstances under which a 100% bonus is granted are not explicitly stated. 

However, we can identify some common characteristics among the social welfare payments that are eligible for the bonus. 

In the 2020 Regulations (DEASP-84), the bonus payment applies to recipients of social welfare payments who have been in receipt of certain payments for a specified period, such as jobseeker’s benefit, Covid-19 pandemic unemployment payment, or jobseeker’s allowance in respect of not less than 104 days or 17 weeks of unemployment. 

In the 2021 Regulations (DEASP-108), the bonus payment applies to recipients of partial capacity benefit, disablement pension, death benefit under the Occupational Injury Benefit scheme, carer’s benefit, State pension (contributory), invalidity pension, and other specified payments. 

In the 2022 Regulations (DEASP-152), the bonus payment applies to recipients of long-term social welfare payments, including blind pension, carer’s allowance, carer’s benefit, death benefit under the Occupational Injury Benefit scheme, and other specified payments. 

In the 2023 Regulations (DEASP-175), the bonus payment applies to recipients of long-term social welfare payments, including partial capacity benefit, disablement pension, death benefit under the Occupational Injury Benefit scheme, carer’s benefit, State pension (contributory), invalidity pension, and other specified payments. 

Based on these passages, it appears that the 100% bonus is granted to recipients of long-term social welfare payments who meet certain eligibility criteria, such as being in receipt of a specified payment for a specified period. However, the specific circumstances under which a 100% bonus is granted are not explicitly stated. 

Therefore, the answer to the question is:

Recipients of social welfare payments are entitled to a 100% bonus under the Social Welfare (Temporary Provisions) Regulations if they meet certain eligibility criteria, such as being in receipt of a long-term social welfare payment for a specified period. However, the specific circumstances under which a 100% bonus is granted are not explicitly stated in the provided passages.

Answer: Based on the provided passages, the 2020 Amendment Regulations extend the exemption under the Waste Management (Prohibition of Waste Disposal by Burning) Regulations 2009 (S.I. 286 of 2009) until 1 January 2022, allowing farmers to dispose of wastes generated by agricultural practices in accordance with the waste hierarchy and as a last resort.

3. (1) An application by an authorised officer under section 148S(7) of the 
Act of 2004 for an order under section 148S(8) of the Act of 2004 must be made 
by way of notice of application. 

(2) Applications under this rule must be brought in the court area in which 
the person in respect of whom the application is made resides or carries on any 
profession, trade or business. 

(3) The notice of application must be in Form No. 40C.01, Schedule C, 

modified as appropriate to the case, and must: 

(i) 

show on its face how or by whom the consent of the Board to the 
making of the application was given; 

(ii) where the requirement to which the application relates was made 
in writing, have appended (to the original notice of application 
and to any copy of the notice of application served on the 
respondent) a true copy of the written requirement, and include 
particulars of service of the requirement on the respondent or 
delivery of the requirement to the respondent; 

 
 
 6 [431] 

(iii) 

 where the requirement to which the application relates was not 
made in writing, include particulars of the requirement and of 
how it was communicated to the respondent. 

(4) The notice of application must be entitled in the matter of section 148S 
of the Residential Tenancies Act 2004, as amended and must contain the name 
and address of the applicant as claimant and the name and address of the 
respondent. 

(5) The return date of the notice of application must be not less than 21 days 

after the date on which the notice of application is issued. 

(6) The respondent must be served not later than 21 days before the return 
date where service is by registered post or not less than seven days before the 
return date where service is effected personally. 

(7) The original notice of application and a statutory declaration as to the 
service of the notice of application on the respondent must be lodged with the 
Clerk not later than four days before the return date. 

Applications by authorised officers or the Board under Schedule 3

Answer:
The 2021 Regulations alter the waiting periods and validity references in Regulation 11 of the 2018 Regulations relevant to labour market access permissions as follows:

- The timeframe for labour market access is reduced from 9 months to 6 months.
- The validity of a labour market permission is extended from 6 months to 12 months.

These changes apply to applications for labour market access permission under Regulation 11(3) of the 2018 Regulations, as well as to renewals of permissions under Regulation 11(7) of the 2018 Regulations, where the application has been made before the date on which the 2021 Regulations come into operation and has not been determined by the Minister.

A person who purchases a dwelling on or after the commencement of these Regulations ceases to qualify as a 'relevant owner' for the scheme if they knew, or ought to have known, that defective concrete blocks were used in the construction of the dwelling at the time of purchase.

The maximum grant amount available under the Dwelling Grant Scheme is €420,000 per dwelling.

Offence
Answer:
An authorised officer may exercise the following inspection and information-gathering powers to ensure compliance:

1. Entering any place (other than a private dwelling) at which the officer has reasonable grounds to believe records are kept relating to assistance from the European Funds or any activities relating to such assistance.
2. Requiring the owner or any person employed at the place to provide their name, home address, and occupation, as well as any records in their power or control, and to give information about any entries in such records.
3. Inspecting and taking copies of or extracts from records, including information in non-legible form, at the place referred to in (1).
4. Inspecting and copying or extracting information from any data, including personal data, found or provided to the officer.
5. Requiring any person who has used data equipment to afford the officer all reasonable assistance in relation to its use.
6. Removing and retaining any records for a reasonable period for further examination.
7. Securing for later inspection the place or part of any place in which records are kept or where there are reasonable grounds for believing records are kept.
8. Summoning any other person concerned in relation to assistance received from the European Funds or any activities relating to such assistance to give information or produce records.

However, there is a constraint on entering a private dwelling. An authorised officer may only enter a private dwelling if it is not specified as a place that may be entered under the Regulation.

Answer:
A person who is guilty of an offence under Regulation 6 shall be liable to the following penalties on conviction:

- On summary conviction: 
  - A class A fine
  - Imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months
  - Both a fine and imprisonment

- On conviction on indictment:
  - A fine not exceeding €500,000
  - Imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years
  - Both a fine and imprisonment

Answer:
An affidavit may be sworn using videoconference under the following circumstances:

1. The deponent is not physically present before the officer due to reasons stated briefly in the affidavit.
2. The deponent resides outside the State, or is for the time being outside the State, and the affidavit is sworn before any person authorized by law to administer oaths in the place where the person making the affidavit resides or is.

To be sworn using videoconference, the following procedural safeguards must be observed by the officer administering the oath:

1. The officer shall be provided with a copy (which may be in electronic form) of the affidavit, copies of any exhibits referred to in it, and, in a case where rule 6(b)(iii) applies, a certified copy of the relevant document intended to be used to verify the deponent's identity.
2. The officer shall be satisfied that the videoconference facility enables the deponent to see and hear the officer and to be seen and heard by the officer.
3. In a case to which rule 6(b)(ii) applies, the officer shall ensure that the requirement for identification of the deponent has been met before the affidavit is sworn.
4. The officer shall satisfy himself that the appropriate sacred text for taking the oath is available to the deponent.
5. During the videoconference and within sight and hearing of the officer, the deponent shall produce the original of any relevant document intended to be used to verify the deponent's identity, identify each page of the affidavit and any and every exhibit referred to in it, sign or mark any and every exhibit, and sign and swear the affidavit.
6. The sworn affidavit and any and every exhibit referred to in it shall immediately following the videoconference be sent to the officer, for attestation by the officer.
7. The officer shall before attesting the affidavit and signing or marking any and every exhibit referred to in it, satisfy himself that the document (and each and any exhibit) is the same as that which had been identified to him during the videoconference, and, where relevant, sign and append to the affidavit the certified copy of the relevant document used to verify the deponent's identity.
8. The jurat of the affidavit shall indicate the date on which the affidavit was made by the deponent, the place at which the officer was when taking the affidavit, and the fact that the affidavit was sworn using a videoconference.

These procedural safeguards are outlined in the District Court Rules 1997 (S.I. No. 93 of 1997) and are applicable to the swearing of affidavits using videoconference in civil proceedings in the District Court.

18. 

(1) Subject to rule 19, where an intending deponent is not capable of 
making an affidavit in one of the official languages of the State, he or she 
shall make an affidavit in another language which he understands (in this 
rule and rules 19 and 20 referred to as a “foreign language affidavit”). 

(2) A foreign language affidavit shall be translated into one of the 
official languages of the State by a translator who is suitably qualified for 
the purpose. 

(3) Where a foreign language affidavit is to be filed or lodged in court, 
an affidavit of the translator shall (as the case may be) be filed or lodged 
at the same time in which: 

(i) 

the translator sets out his qualifications as a translator, 

(ii) 

a copy of the foreign language affidavit and the original 
translation referred to in sub-rule (2) are exhibited, and 

(iii) 

the translator confirms that the translation is accurate. 

(4) The original translation referred to in sub-rule (2) shall in addition be 
filed or lodged with the affidavit of the translator referred to in sub-rule 
(3).
Answer:
A person taking an affidavit must fulfill the following requirements when the deponent is illiterate or unable to understand an official language of the State:

1. Ensure that the affidavit is read in their presence to the deponent and that the deponent has fully understood it (Rule 19(2)(a)).
2. In any case where the deponent appears not to be capable of understanding one of the official languages of the State, ensure that the affidavit is made as a foreign language affidavit in accordance with Rule 18 and is read to the deponent by a suitably qualified interpreter in the presence of the person taking the affidavit (Rule 19(2)(b)).
3. Certify in the jurat that the affidavit was read in their presence to the deponent (in a case to which paragraph (b) refers, by a suitably qualified interpreter), that the deponent fully understood it, and that the deponent made their signature or mark in their presence (Rule 19(2)(c)).

Additionally, when a foreign language affidavit is to be filed or lodged in court, the person taking the affidavit must also ensure that:

- The translator's affidavit referred to in Rule 18(3) is filed or lodged at the same time (Rule 19(3)).
- The interpreter's affidavit is filed or lodged at the same time, setting out their qualifications as an interpreter, exhibiting a copy of the foreign language affidavit, and confirming that they read accurately to the deponent the contents of the foreign language affidavit (Rule 19(3)).

Note that the Statutory Declarations Act 1938 is referenced in Rule 19(4), but the specific requirements of this Act are not provided in the given passages.

Recognition of certificates of qualification and service record book

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

These Regulations give effect to the derogation set out in Article 39(3) of 
Directive (EU) 2017/2397, as amended, on the recognition of professional 
qualifications in inland navigation. The Regulations provide for the recognition 
by the State of certificates of qualification and service record books, held by 
crew in the field of inland navigation, which are recognised as being valid on 
all EU inland waterways, including inland waterways in the State. The 
Regulations also make provision for cooperating with other Member States 
regarding suspension of such certificates and the recording of navigation time 
and journeys for holders of service record books.

1. (1) These Regulations may be cited as the European Union (Recognition 

of Professional Qualifications in Inland Navigation) Regulations 2021. 

(2) These Regulations come into operation on 17 January 2022. 

Interpretation
Answer:
To whom do these Regulations on recognition of professional qualifications in inland navigation apply, and what categories of persons are expressly excluded from their scope?

These Regulations apply to the recognition of Union certificates of qualification, other such certificates, and service record books referred to in Regulations 4 and 5. 

The categories of persons expressly excluded from the scope of these Regulations are:

- Persons navigating for sport or pleasure
- Persons involved in the operation of ferries not moving independently
- Persons involved in the operation of craft used by armed forces, forces maintaining public order, civil defence services, waterway administrations, fire services, and other emergency services
- Navigators on inland waterways in the State who are exclusively:
  - Navigating limited journeys of local interest, where the distance from the departure point is at no time more than 10 kilometres
  - Navigating seasonally

6. (1) Where the MSO determines that a certificate of qualification issued 
by a competent authority in another Member State does not satisfy conditions 
laid down by the Directive, or where there are reasons of safety or public order, 
the MSO shall request the issuing authority to consider suspending that 
certificate of qualification pursuant to Article 14 of the Directive. 

(2) The MSO may prohibit a person from operating on inland waterways in 
the State pending notification of the issuing authority’s decision regarding the 
request referred to in paragraph (1) in respect of the person. 

(3) Where the MSO prohibits a person under paragraph (2) it shall serve on 
the person a prohibition notice to that effect in writing by delivering it to the 
person or sending it by post or, if the MSO has an electronic address for the 
person, by electronic means. 

(4) A person who fails to comply with a prohibition notice served on him 
or her under paragraph (3) commits an offence and is liable on summary 
conviction to a class C fine. 

(5) Summary proceedings for an offence under paragraph (4) may be 

brought and prosecuted by the MSO. 

3 OJ No. L 255, 30.9.2005, p. 22 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 6 [442] 

Cooperation with other Member States – recording of navigation time

4. (1) Any Union certificate of qualification carried by deck crew 
members, passenger navigation experts and liquefied natural gas experts, as 
well as any service record books that have been issued by a competent 
authority in another Member State in accordance with the Directive, shall be 
valid in respect of the holder on all inland waterways in the State. 

(2) Any certificate of qualification or service record book issued in 
accordance with the Regulations for Rhine Navigation Personnel, which lay 
down requirements that are identical to those of the Directive, shall be valid in 
respect of the holder on all inland waterways in the State. Such certificates and 
service record books that have been issued by a third country shall be valid on 
all inland waterways in the State, provided that that third country recognises, 
within its jurisdiction, European Union documents issued pursuant to the 
Directive. 

(3) Without prejudice to paragraph (2), any certificate of qualification or 
service record book that has been issued in accordance with the national rules 
of a third country laying down requirements that are identical to those of the 
Directive, including those set out in Article 38(1) and (3) of the Directive, shall 
be valid in respect of the holder on all inland waterways in the State, subject to 
such certificates or service record books being granted recognition in the 
European Union in accordance with the procedure and the conditions set out in 
paragraphs (4) and (5) of Article 10 of the Directive. 

 
 
 
 [442] 5 

(4) When the MSO considers that a third country no longer complies with 
the requirements of Article 10 of the Directive, it shall notify the European 
Commission immediately, giving substantiated reasons for its contention. 

Recognition of valid certificates – transitional measures
Answer:
When the Marine Survey Office (MSO) determines that a certificate of qualification issued by a competent authority in another Member State fails to meet Directive conditions or raises safety concerns, the procedure is as follows:

1. The MSO shall request the issuing authority to consider suspending that certificate of qualification pursuant to Article 14 of the Directive (Paragraph 6.1).
2. The MSO may prohibit a person from operating on inland waterways in the State pending notification of the issuing authority's decision regarding the request referred to in paragraph (1) in respect of the person (Paragraph 6.2).
3. If the MSO prohibits a person under paragraph (2), it shall serve on the person a prohibition notice to that effect in writing by delivering it to the person or sending it by post or, if the MSO has an electronic address for the person, by electronic means (Paragraph 6.3).
4. A person who fails to comply with a prohibition notice served on them under paragraph (3) commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a class C fine (Paragraph 6.4).
5. Summary proceedings for an offence under paragraph (4) may be brought and prosecuted by the MSO (Paragraph 6.5).

Additionally, if the MSO considers that a third country no longer complies with the requirements of Article 10 of the Directive, it shall notify the European Commission immediately, giving substantiated reasons for its contention (Paragraph 4).

Enforcement, Amendment, Suspension and Withdrawal
Answer:
A Licensee must comply with the following obligations under Regulation 6 to maintain lawful operation of apparatus under the Wireless Telegraphy (Further Temporary Electronic Communications Services Licences) (No. 3) Regulations 2021:

1. Ensure that it complies with the conditions in its Licence and with these Regulations.
2. Ensure that any Apparatus in the 700 MHz Duplex complies with the Decision of 2016 and that any Apparatus in the 2.1 GHz Band complies with the Decision of 2012.
3. Ensure that all Apparatus installed, maintained, possessed or kept under the Licence is capable of operating within the radio frequency spectrum specified in the Licence.
4. Ensure that all Apparatus worked or used under the Licence is worked or used only in the radio frequency spectrum specified in the Licence.
5. Ensure that it makes payment of the fee set out in and in accordance with Regulation 8.
6. Furnish such information in respect of the Licence as may be requested by the Commission from time to time.
7. Ensure that all Apparatus, or any part thereof, is installed, maintained, worked and used so as not to cause Harmful Interference.
8. Ensure that all Apparatus, or any part thereof, complies with the Radio Equipment Regulations.
9. Comply with any special conditions imposed under section 8 of the Act of 1972.
10. Upon becoming aware of any event likely to materially affect its ability to comply with these Regulations, or any conditions set out or referred to in any Licence, notify the Commission of that fact in writing no later than 5 working days upon becoming aware.
11. Comply with all obligations under relevant international agreements relating to the use of Apparatus or the frequencies to which they are assigned under a Licence.

Answer:
The amendments introduced to the definition of 'Directive' under the European Communities (Intra-Community Transfers of Defence Related Products) Regulations 2011 by the 2021 amending Regulations include the addition of the following directives:

- Commission Directive (EU) 2021/1047 of 5 March 2021 amending Directive 2009/43/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards the updating of the list of defence-related products in line with the updated Common Military List of the European Union of 17 February 2020.

However, this directive is not present in the 2023 and 2024 amending Regulations. 

The 2023 amending Regulations introduce the following directives:

- Commission Delegated Directive (EU) 2023/277 of 5 October 2022 amending Directive 2009/43/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards the updating of the list of defence-related products in line with the updated Common Military List of the European Union of 21 February 2022.

The 2024 amending Regulations introduce the following directives:

- Commission Delegated Directive (EU) 2024/242 of 27 September 2023 amending Directive 2009/43/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards the updating of the list of defence-related products in line with the updated Common Military List of the European Union of 20 February 2023.

The 2021 amending Regulations do not introduce any new directives that are not already present in the 2023 and 2024 amending Regulations.

However, based on the standard format of statutory instruments in Ireland, it can be inferred that the delegated ministerial powers were exercised by the Minister for the Gaeltacht.

Therefore, while the specific details of the delegation instrument are not provided, it can be assumed that the Minister for the Gaeltacht exercised the delegated ministerial powers under the Gaeltacht Act 2012 to make these Orders, and that those powers were conferred through a delegation instrument made by the Government.

The legislative provisions extended by the Companies Act 2014 (Section 12A(1)) (Covid-19) (No. 2) Order 2021 are sections 3 to 9, section 11, sections 13 to 16, and sections 18 to 25 of the Act of 2020.

The interim period is specified as follows:

- The period beginning on 1 January 2021 and ending on 9 June 2021 (as specified in the Order dated 15 December 2020).
- The period beginning on 10 June 2021 and ending on 31 December 2021 (as specified in the Order dated 18 May 2021).

Therefore, the interim period is extended for a total duration of approximately 14 months, from 1 January 2021 to 31 December 2021.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

This Order extends, until 19th June 2020, the operation of the amendments 
effected by Part 2 of the Health (Preservation and Protection and other 
Emergency Measures in the Public Interest) Act 2020 [No. 1 of 2020] to the 
Social Welfare Consolidation Act 2005. These provisions currently expire on 
9th May 2020. 

The effect of the extension is to allow the payment of enhanced Illness Benefit 
to those who are diagnosed with Covid-19 or who are deemed to be a probable 
source of infection of same or by order under the Health Act 1947 until the 19th 
of June. This Order also allows the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social 
Protection to extend until the same date, by regulation, the waiving of the three 
day waiting period for Jobseeker's Benefit and Jobseeker's Allowance.

The purpose of the 'interim period' it extends is to allow the payment of enhanced Illness Benefit to those who are diagnosed with Covid-19 or who are deemed to be a probable source of infection of same or by order under the Health Act 1947 until the 19th of June. This order also enables the Minister for Employment Affairs and Social Protection to extend until the same date, by regulation, the waiving of the three-day waiting period for Jobseeker's Benefit and Jobseeker's Allowance.

Answer:
To answer your question, the activities within the Crosswood Bog Special Area of Conservation that require prior consent from the Minister under Regulation 5 are:

1. Reclamation, including infilling (ARC 01)
2. Blasting, drilling, dredging or otherwise removing or disturbing fossils, rock, minerals, mud, sand, gravel or other sediment (ARC 03)
3. All activities relating to turf cutting and/or peat extraction (ARC 04)
4. Cutting, uprooting or otherwise removing plants (ARC 05)
5. Introduction, or re-introduction, of plants or animals not found in the area (ARC 06)
6. Construction or alteration of tracks, paths, roads, bridges, culverts or access routes (ARC 09)
7. Digging, ploughing, harrowing or otherwise disturbing soil or substrate (ARC 11)
8. Applying inorganic or organic fertiliser, including slurry and farmyard manure (ARC 12)
9. Applying lime (ARC 13)
10. Storage, burial, disposal or recovery of any materials (ARC 14)
11. Burning, topping, clearing scrub or rough vegetation or reseeding (ARC 15)
12. Application of pesticides, including herbicides (ARC 18)
13. Supplementary feeding of livestock (ARC 19)
14. Significant changes in livestock density (including introduction of grazing), changes in livestock type or grazing season, other than on established reseeded grassland (ARC 20)
15. Works on, or alterations to, the banks, bed or flow of a drain, watercourse or waterbody (ARC 24)
16. Drainage works including digging, deepening, widening or blocking a drain, watercourse or waterbody (ARC 25)
17. Water abstraction, sinking of boreholes and wells (ARC 27)
18. Felling of trees or removing timber, including dead wood (ARC 28)
19. Planting of trees or multi-annual bioenergy crops (ARC 29)
20. Developing or consenting to the development or operation of commercial recreational/visitor facilities or organised recreational activities (ARC 31)

Exemptions are provided for the following activities:

- Harvesting of cultivated crops
- Grazing or mowing
- Planting of crops on established reseeded grassland or cultivated land
- Digging, ploughing, harrowing or otherwise disturbing soil or substrate on established reseeded grassland or cultivated land, provided it is greater than 50m from a river, stream, floodplain, wetland, lake, turlough or pond
- Applying inorganic or organic fertiliser, including slurry and farmyard manure, on established reseeded grassland or cultivated land, provided it is greater than 20m from a river, stream or floodplain; or greater than 50m from a wetland, lake, turlough or pond
- Applying lime on established reseeded grassland or cultivated land, provided it is greater than 20m from a river, stream or floodplain; or greater than 50m from a wetland, lake, turlough or pond
- Storage, burial, disposal or recovery of any materials on established reseeded grassland or cultivated land, provided it is greater than 20m from a river, stream or floodplain; or greater than 50m from a wetland, lake, turlough or pond
- Burning, topping, clearing scrub or rough vegetation or reseeding on established reseeded grassland or cultivated land, provided it is greater than 20m from a river, stream or floodplain; or greater than 50m from a wetland, lake, turlough or pond
- Application of pesticides, including herbicides, on established reseeded grassland or cultivated land, provided it is greater than 20m from a river

Offence and proceedings
Answer:
Passage: Offence and proceedings

(1) A person who carries out, causes or permits to be carried out or continues to carry out, or assists in carrying out, any activity specified in Schedule 4 within the Special Area of Conservation without the consent of the Minister under Regulation 30 of the Regulations of 2011, is guilty of an offence under these Regulations.

(2) A person guilty of an offence under paragraph (1) is liable on summary conviction to a fine not exceeding €5,000 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months or both.

(3) Proceedings for an offence under paragraph (1) may be brought and prosecuted by the Minister or by any person who has an interest in the land within the Special Area of Conservation.

(4) A person who is convicted of an offence under paragraph (1) is liable to pay to the Minister the costs and expenses of any works or measures that may be required to restore the land to its former condition.

Passage: Enforcement powers

(1) The Minister may, for the purpose of enforcing these Regulations, enter any land within the Special Area of Conservation, at all reasonable times, with or without assistants.

(2) The Minister may, for the purpose of enforcing these Regulations, inspect any equipment, plant or other thing on any land within the Special Area of Conservation.

(3) The Minister may, for the purpose of enforcing these Regulations, require any person to provide information or assistance as may be necessary for the enforcement of these Regulations.

(4) A person who fails to comply with a requirement under paragraph (3) is guilty of an offence under these Regulations.

Answer: 

The penalties and enforcement powers that apply under these Regulations for carrying out prohibited activities in the Special Area of Conservation without Ministerial consent include:

- A fine not exceeding €5,000 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months or both, upon conviction for an offence under these Regulations.
- The Minister or any person who has an interest in the land within the Special Area of Conservation may bring and prosecute proceedings for an offence under these Regulations.
- A person convicted of an offence under these Regulations is liable to pay to the Minister the costs and expenses of any works or measures that may be required to restore the land to its former condition.
- The Minister may enter any land within the Special Area of Conservation, at all reasonable times, with or without assistants, for the purpose of enforcing these Regulations.
- The Minister may inspect any equipment, plant or other thing on any land within the Special Area of Conservation, for the purpose of enforcing these Regulations.
- The Minister may require any person to provide information or assistance as may be necessary for the enforcement of these Regulations.
- A person who fails to comply with a requirement under these Regulations is guilty of an offence under these Regulations.

Answer:
To answer your question, we need to identify the institutions required to pay a levy under these Regulations and the exemption that applies.

The institutions required to pay a levy under these Regulations are:

1. Credit Institutions (Category A)
2. Insurance Undertakings (Category B)
3. Intermediaries and Debt Management Firms (Category C)
4. Investment Business Firms (Category D)
5. Credit Unions (Category F)
6. Moneylenders Approved by the Bank (Category G)
7. Approved Professional Bodies (Category H)
8. Bureaux de Change (Category J)
9. Retail Credit Firms, Home Reversion Firms, and Credit Servicing Firms (Category M)
10. Payment Institutions and E-Money Institutions (Category N)
11. Pawnbrokers (Category O)

The exemption that applies is for Intermediaries who are members of the Society of the Irish Motor Industry ("SIMI") in Category C. According to the Regulations, the SIMI shall pay a flat rate levy of €12,000 for and on behalf of its members who are intermediaries as described in this Category C, and such a payment will discharge those intermediaries' obligation to pay a levy pursuant to these Regulations.

Therefore, the answer to your question is:

The institutions required to pay a levy under these Regulations are listed above, and the exemption that applies is for Intermediaries who are members of the Society of the Irish Motor Industry ("SIMI") in Category C.

Answer:
A person commits an offence under these Regulations if they are found guilty of violating any of the provisions outlined in the Regulations, with the exception of Regulation 63(1), (2), (4), or (5), which carry specific penalties. 

Upon conviction, the penalties for an offence under these Regulations (other than those specified in Regulation 63(1), (2), (4), or (5)) may include:

- A class A fine on summary conviction
- A fine not exceeding €500,000, or imprisonment for a term not exceeding three years, or both, on conviction on indictment

For offences under Regulation 63(1), (2), (4), or (5), the penalties may include:

- A class A fine, imprisonment for a term not exceeding 6 months, the forfeiture of any consideration or advantage obtained in connection with the offence, or the forfeiture of land, cash, or other property of an equivalent value, or any combination of these penalties on summary conviction
- A fine not exceeding €500,000, imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years, the forfeiture of any consideration or advantage obtained in connection with the offence, or the forfeiture of land, cash, or other property of an equivalent value, or any combination of these penalties on conviction on indictment

In addition, if an offence is committed by a body corporate, the individual who consented to, connived in, or approved of the offence, or whose wilful neglect led to the offence, may also be held liable and punished accordingly.

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

These Regulations provide for the enforcement of restrictive measures 
contained in Council Regulation (EU) No. 401/2013 of 2 May 2013 as 
amended, regarding restrictive measures concerning Myanmar/Burma. 

The Regulations provide that competent authorities of the State may issue 
directions for the purpose of giving full effect to the sanctions. 

The Regulations create offences for breach of the Council Regulations or for 
failure to comply with the directions of competent authorities of the State with 
regard to implementation of the sanctions and provide for appropriate 
penalties.

Answer:
Based on the provided passages, the powers granted to competent authorities under these Regulations to ensure compliance with the EU sanctions on Myanmar/Burma are as follows:

Competent authorities of the State may issue directions for the purpose of giving full effect to the sanctions contained in Council Regulation (EU) No. 401/2013 of 2 May 2013 as amended, regarding restrictive measures concerning Myanmar/Burma.

These directions are intended to ensure compliance with the EU sanctions, and competent authorities may take appropriate action to enforce them. The Regulations also create offences for breach of the Council Regulations or for failure to comply with the directions of competent authorities of the State with regard to implementation of the sanctions.

In summary, the powers granted to competent authorities under these Regulations include the ability to issue directions to ensure compliance with the EU sanctions on Myanmar/Burma, and to take appropriate action to enforce these directions, including creating offences for breach or non-compliance.

A person who purchases a dwelling on or after the commencement of these Regulations ceases to qualify as a 'relevant owner' for the scheme if they knew, or ought to have known, that defective concrete blocks were used in the construction of the dwelling at the time of purchase.

The maximum grant amount available under the Dwelling Grant Scheme is €420,000 per dwelling.

To qualify for the scheme, an applicant must submit evidence from a qualified engineer that confirms the presence of defective concrete blocks in the dwelling.

The effective commencement date for the remaining provisions of the CervicalCheck Tribunal Act 2019 under this Order is the 23rd day of May 2022.

of 1961), is hereby amended by the substitution at reference number 65 for the 
matter in column (4) of the following: 

“Letterkenny – First, Second, Third and Fourth Monday in each 
month. First Tuesday in each month. First and Second 
Wednesday in each month. First, Third and Fourth Thursday in 
each month. All sitting at 10.30am “

3. The Second Schedule to the District Court (Areas) Order, 1961 (S.I. 
No. 5 of 1961), is hereby amended by the substitution at reference number 59 
for the matter in column (4) of the following: 

“Letterkenny – First, Second, Third and Fourth Monday in each 
month. First Tuesday in each month. First and Second 
Wednesday in each month. First, Third and Fourth Thursday in 
each month. All sitting at 10.30am “
Answer:
The sitting schedule for the Letterkenny District Court under this Order is amended by substituting the following days for sittings:

- First, Second, Third, and Fourth Monday in each month
- First Tuesday in each month
- First and Second Wednesday in each month
- First, Third, and Fourth Thursday in each month

All sittings will take place at 10.30am. 

These amendments are made to the First Schedule (reference number 65) and the Second Schedule (reference number 59) of the District Court (Areas) Order, 1961 (S.I. No. 5 of 1961).

1. This Order may be cited as the Civil Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) 

Act 2022 (Parts 2 and 3) (Commencement) Order 2022.
Answer:
A person who purchases a dwelling on or after the commencement of these Regulations ceases to qualify as a 'relevant owner' for the scheme if they knew, or ought to have known, that defective concrete blocks were used in the construction of the dwelling at the time of purchase.

The maximum grant amount available under the Dwelling Grant Scheme is €420,000 per dwelling.

To qualify for the scheme, an applicant must submit evidence from a qualified engineer that confirms the presence of defective concrete blocks in the dwelling.

Now, to answer the question:

The Minister responsible for bringing Parts 2 and 3 of the Civil Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2022 into operation under this Order is the Minister for Children, Equality, Disability, Integration and Youth, Roderic O'Gorman.

persons in joint R&D projects.
Answer:
Regulation 2 does not define the scope of undertakings to which the Business Expenditure on Research and Development Survey Order 2022 applies. However, Regulation 1 provides the scope of the survey, which includes information regarding the following:

- The nature of its business activity insofar as it relates to R&D in 2021.
- Expenditure on in-house R&D activity in 2021.
- Estimated expenditure on in-house R&D activity in 2022.
- Sources of funds for in-house R&D activity performed in 2021 and the amount in euro from each source concerned.
- Categories of in-house R&D activity performed in 2021 and the expenditure on each category concerned.
- The number of persons involved in in-house R&D activity in 2021 including, in relation to each such person, his or her role, qualifications and gender and the amount of time spent by him or her on that activity.
- R&D activity at local unit level in 2021.
- Expenditure on R&D activity performed on behalf of the undertaking by other persons in 2021.
- By reference to the qualifications of the persons concerned, whether the undertaking is likely, in the period commencing on 1 January 2022 and ending on 31 December 2027, to increase the number of persons involved in in-house R&D activity.
- Engagement in 2021 by the undertaking with other persons in joint R&D projects.

Therefore, the scope of undertakings to which the Business Expenditure on Research and Development Survey Order 2022 applies includes all undertakings that engage in R&D activities and are required to provide the information specified in Regulation 1.

5.

(1) For the purposes of the operation and administration of the Scheme, an electricity 

supplier shall—

(a) receive monies transferred to it by the distribution system operator under section 

4(1)(f),

(b) use monies received by it under paragraph (a) for the sole purpose of making 

electricity costs emergency benefit payments,

(c) keep records of—

(i) all monies received in accordance with paragraph (a), and

(ii) all electricity costs emergency benefit payments made by it,

(d) as soon as practicable, repay to the distribution system operator any monies 
received by it in accordance with paragraph (a) that have not been used for the 
purpose of making electricity costs emergency benefit payments and keep records 
of any such repayments,

(e) perform such other functions as the Minster may, with the consent of the Minister 
for Public Expenditure and Reform, for the purposes of the efficient operation 
and administration of the Scheme, prescribe, and

(f) make available to an auditor appointed by the Minister all books and records in 
relation to the performance by the electricity supplier of the functions conferred 
on it by or under this Act.

(2) Where an electricity supplier receives monies in accordance with subsection (1)(a), it 
shall, within such period ending not later than 31 December 2023 as the Minister, 
with the consent of the Minister for Public Expenditure and Reform, prescribes for the 
purposes of this subsection in respect of each payment period, credit each domestic 
electricity account held with it on the effective date in respect of the payment period 
concerned, with a payment of €183.49 (in this Act referred to as an “electricity costs 
emergency benefit payment”).

(3) An electricity supplier shall, for the purpose of the Scheme, put in place such 
administrative and operational arrangements that the Commission considers necessary 
or expedient under section 9Q(1)(a) of the Act of 1999.

 Publishing yearly lists of legislation 

Using the ELI URI standard a yearly list of legislation is displayed by the following URI 
syntax; 
/eli/{year}/{type – “act” or “si”} 

Examples 

http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/2014/act 
(will display the list of Acts (public, private and constitutional amendments) for 2014 
including bi-lingual Act titles if applicable 

 http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/2014/si/ 
(will display the list of Statutory Instruments for 2014) 

Multiple format versions

legislation

Answer:
To answer the question, we need to refer to Regulation 9 of the provided passages. 

Regulation 9 gives the Minister the power to approve persons manufacturing or supplying bovine identification devices. Specifically, under Regulation 9(1), the Minister has approved certain persons for the purposes of these Regulations to manufacture, sell, and supply conventional ear-tags and electronic identification devices. 

However, under Regulation 9(2), the Minister may grant an approval for the purposes of these Regulations in respect of the manufacture, sale, and supply of a type of conventional ear-tag or electronic identification device that incorporates an electronic identifier bearing the identification code of a bovine within the meaning of Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) 2019/2035 of 28 June 2019.

In addition, under Regulation 9(3), the Minister may attach conditions to an approval under this Regulation, vary or revoke a condition, or attach a new condition. The conditions may relate to various matters, including the provision of documents relating to bovines, technical standards relating to means of identification, arrangements for access to the Minister's Animal Identification and Movement System (AIM), and security of means of identification, equipment, records, and information.

The Minister also has the power to refuse an application or suspend or revoke an approval under Regulation 9(7), if, in his or her opinion, the applicant or person to whom the approval is granted has been convicted of an offence, has failed to comply with a condition of an approval, has furnished false or misleading information, or is not a fit and proper person to be approved.

Finally, under Regulation 9(8), the Minister shall notify the applicant or person to whom the approval is granted of the proposal to refuse an application or suspend or revoke an approval, and shall consider any representations made before deciding whether to proceed with, modify, or annul the proposal.

Therefore, the Minister has the following powers under Regulation 9 in relation to the approval of persons manufacturing or supplying bovine identification devices:

- To approve persons for the manufacture, sale, and supply of conventional ear-tags and electronic identification devices
- To grant an approval for the manufacture, sale, and supply of a type of conventional ear-tag or electronic identification device that incorporates an electronic identifier bearing the identification code of a bovine
- To attach conditions to an approval, vary or revoke a condition, or attach a new condition
- To refuse an application or suspend or revoke an approval if the applicant or person to whom the approval is granted has been convicted of an offence, has failed to comply with a condition of an approval, has furnished false or misleading information, or is not a fit and proper person to be approved
- To notify the applicant or person to whom the approval is granted of the proposal to refuse an application or suspend or revoke an approval, and to consider any representations made before deciding whether to proceed with, modify, or annul the proposal.

This Order appoints 15 May 2023 as the date on which Part 2 (with the 
exception of Chapter 9) of the Maritime Area Planning Act 2021 (No. 50 of 
2021) comes into operation. 

Part 2 provides for the preparation and publication of Maritime Spatial Plans; 
for the designation of public bodies who may make Designated Maritime Area 
Plans, and for the preparation and publication of Designated Maritime Area 
Plans. The Part also provides for judicial review of Maritime Spatial Plans and 
Designated Maritime Area Plans and for compliance by public bodies with the 
National Marine Planning Framework.

Answer:
A person who purchases a dwelling on or after the commencement of these Regulations ceases to qualify as a 'relevant owner' for the scheme if they knew, or ought to have known, that defective concrete blocks were used in the construction of the dwelling at the time of purchase.

However, the provided passage does not seem to be relevant to the question about the commencement date specified in Regulation 2 of this Order. 

The passage you provided seems to be related to the rules of civil procedure, specifically the rules for dismissing an action for want of prosecution in tort or contract cases. 

To answer your question, the legal effect produced by the commencement date specified in Regulation 2 of this Order is that it restricts the ability of a defendant to serve a notice of motion to dismiss an action for want of prosecution, unless certain conditions are met. 

Specifically, the defendant must give the plaintiff at least 28 days' prior written notice of their intention to serve a notice of motion to dismiss, and the plaintiff must be given an opportunity to deliver a statement of claim within 28 days of the date of the letter. If the plaintiff fails to deliver a statement of claim within this period, the defendant may serve a notice of motion to dismiss the action for want of prosecution, with costs.

The categories of licences defined under Regulation 2 of this Order for the purposes of Tailte Éireann’s geospatial operations are:

1. Copyright licence: a licence granted by Tailte Éireann to produce a copy of a product, specified in Part 1 or 3 of Schedule 2, for a specified purpose.
2. Data licence agreement: a licence for the use, distribution, and access of one or more data sets specified in column 2 of Schedule 3.

The categories of digital models defined under Regulation 2 of this Order for the purposes of Tailte Éireann’s geospatial operations are:

1. Digital Cartographic Model (DCM): a digital representation of the national map where the data is supplied in raster format after cartographic design has been applied.
2. Digital Landscape Model (DLM): a digital representation of the national map, at different resolutions, where the data is supplied in vector format with no cartographic design applied.
3. Digital Terrain Model (DTM): a 3-dimensional digital representation of a terrain surface.

Answer:
The enforcement powers of competent authorities under these Regulations to ensure compliance with EU sanctions concerning Iraq include the ability to issue directions for the purpose of giving full effect to the sanctions. 

These directions can be issued by competent authorities of the State to ensure that the restrictive measures contained in Council Regulation (EU) No. 1210/2003 of 7 July 2003, as amended, are implemented effectively. 

In addition to issuing directions, the Regulations also create offences for breach of the Council Regulation or for failure to comply with the directions of competent authorities of the State with regard to implementation of the sanctions. 

Therefore, competent authorities possess the power to issue directions and to enforce compliance with EU sanctions concerning Iraq through the creation of offences and the imposition of appropriate penalties.

Answer:
A person who is eligible for Domiciliary Care Allowance may continue to receive payment under Regulation 140E when a qualified child resides in an institution in the following specific circumstances:

1. The qualified child is immediately admitted to an institution on a full-time basis for the purpose of receiving medical or other treatment of a temporary nature.
2. The qualified child is a child born on or after 1 January 2023, and remains in hospital or is transferred to another hospital for medical or other treatment.

In these circumstances, the qualified child shall be regarded as normally residing with the qualified person, and the qualified person shall be regarded as providing for the care of the child, despite the child's temporary residence in an institution.

Answer:
These Regulations modify the treatment of income from renting out a room under the Social Welfare framework by extending the duration of the disregard for income received from renting out a room in a person's home to a person who is not an employee or an immediate family member.

The maximum amount of income that can be disregarded is €269.23 weekly, which equates to €14,000 per annum.

The duration of the disregard has been extended as follows:

- Initially, the disregard was extended until 17 March 2025 by the Social Welfare (Consolidated Claims, Payments and Control) (Amendment) (No. 10) (Income Disregard) Regulations 2022 (S.I. No. 397 of 2022).
- Then, it was extended until 17 March 2027 by the Social Welfare (Consolidated Claims, Payments and Control) (Amendment) (No. 4) (Income Disregard) Regulations 2023.

Therefore, under these Regulations, the disregard will continue until 17 March 2027.

1. This Order may be cited as the Finance (Covid-19 and Miscellaneous 

Provisions) Act 2022 (Section 15(1)) (Commencement) Order 2023.
Answer:
The legal effect of Regulation 2 in determining when section 15(1) of the Finance (Covid-19 and Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2022 comes into operation is that it appoints the 5th day of April 2023 as the day on which subsection (1) of section 15 of the Finance (Covid-19 and Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2022 (No. 9 of 2022) shall come into operation.

This means that section 15(1) of the Finance (Covid-19 and Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2022 will be deemed to have come into operation on the 5th day of April 2023, in accordance with the provisions of the Finance (Covid-19 and Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 2022 (Section 15(1)) (Commencement) Order 2023.

Answer:
A person installing a reverse vending machine under Class 42A must meet the following specific planning and safety conditions:

1. The opening of the reverse vending machine must be located on an inner wall of the shop.
2. The storage unit and associated roofed area must be developed to the outside of the shop.
3. The reverse vending machine, together with the storage unit and associated roofed area, must operate ancillary to the shop.

These conditions are outlined in Class 42A of Part 1 of Schedule 2 to the Principal Regulations.

Offence and proceedings
Answer:
According to Regulation 5, the types of activities within the Lower River Shannon Special Area of Conservation that require ministerial consent are those specified in Schedule 4.

However, there is a statutory exception that applies under paragraph (2) of Regulation 5. Specifically, a person is not required to obtain ministerial consent under paragraph (1) if the proposed or continued activity falls under one of the following categories:

- (a) The activity requires consent or consents under one or more of the enactments set out in the Second Schedule to the Regulations of 2011 or under the Planning and Development Acts 2000 to 2015, and the activity is carried out with and in compliance with such consent or consents.
- (b) There is no specific information provided in the passage for option (b).
- (c) The activity is part of a project that has received consent under one or more of the enactments set out in the Second Schedule to the Regulations of 2011 or under the Planning and Development Acts 2000 to 2015, and the project or activity is carried out with and in compliance with a consent or consents given under the applicable statutes.
- (d) The activity has been authorised as part of an agreed farm or land management plan.

In all these cases, the requirement for ministerial consent under Regulation 5(1) is waived, and the person can proceed with the activity without obtaining consent from the Minister.

as a Returning Officer and a substitute returning officer, who shall act in the

(2) In this bye-law, any reference to the Returning Officer in relation to any 
act, matter or function for which a Returning Officer is appointed by or under 
this bye-law shall, unless the context otherwise requires, be interpreted as 
including a reference to the substitute returning officer. 

(3) The Returning Officer will ensure, insofar as it is possible, that neither 
he or she, nor any person employed by him or her, has any conflict of interest,

is or has been a Candidate,

is a Relative of a Candidate at that Election.

the purposes of conducting the Election. 

(5) The Returning Officer may, if he or she considers it necessary for the 
performance of his or her duties, and with the consent of Council, appoint such 
person or persons as he or she considers fit and proper to assist him or her. 

(6) The Returning Officer or any person appointed by him or her for any 
purpose relating to the Election shall not be a Candidate or an agent of a 
Candidate or a Relative of a Candidate at that Election or associated in 
furthering the candidature of any Candidate at that Election. 

(7) The Returning Officer shall not appoint for any purpose relating to the 

Election a person who to the knowledge of the Returning Officer – 

(a) 

is or has been a Candidate, 

(b) has been associated in furthering the candidature of a Candidate, 

or 

(c) 

is a Relative of a Candidate at that Election. 

(8) The Council shall defray the reasonable expenses of a Returning 

Officer in conducting an Election. 

Powers and functions of Returning Officer

5. (1) The Council shall appoint persons of competence and integrity to act 
as a Returning Officer and a substitute returning officer, who shall act in the 
event that the Returning Officer is unable or unavailable to act, for the purpose 
of each Election. 

(2) In this bye-law, any reference to the Returning Officer in relation to any 
act, matter or function for which a Returning Officer is appointed by or under 
this bye-law shall, unless the context otherwise requires, be interpreted as 
including a reference to the substitute returning officer. 

(3) The Returning Officer will ensure, insofar as it is possible, that neither 
he or she, nor any person employed by him or her, has any conflict of interest, 
and will avoid any perceived conflict of interest, in relation to the running of the 
Election. Should a conflict of interest arise, in relation to the Returning Officer, 
he or she will immediately notify the Council and the substitute Returning 
Officer will take over the running of the Election. In the case of a conflict arising 
with an employee, the Returning Officer will discontinue that employee’s 
involvement in the Election.

Powers and functions of Returning Officer
Answer:
The authority responsible for appointing the Returning Officer is the Council. 

To manage conflicts of interest during the election process, the Returning Officer must ensure, insofar as it is possible, that neither they nor any person employed by them has any conflict of interest, and will avoid any perceived conflict of interest, in relation to the running of the Election. 

If a conflict of interest arises, the Returning Officer must immediately notify the Council, and the substitute Returning Officer will take over the running of the Election. In the case of a conflict arising with an employee, the Returning Officer will discontinue that employee's involvement in the Election. 

Additionally, the Returning Officer shall not appoint for any purpose relating to the Election a person who to the knowledge of the Returning Officer:

- is or has been a Candidate,
- has been associated in furthering the candidature of a Candidate,
- is a Relative of a Candidate at that Election.

Answer:
The procedural powers granted to the Returning Officer under Regulation 5 to ensure the validity and integrity of the election process include:

1. Determining all questions of procedure, form, or manner in which the Election shall take place, including the manner in which the system of proportional representation shall be conducted.
2. Ensuring the validity and integrity of the nomination and Election processes.
3. Making decisions with regard to the qualification or disqualification of candidates.
4. Calculating quotas.
5. Making decisions in respect of valid, invalid, or spoiled votes.
6. Conducting counts.
7. Transferring votes.
8. Determining the form and content of all nomination papers, ballot papers, declarations, instructions, advertisements, and notices required to be issued in accordance with this bye-law.
9. Setting the date for establishing the Electoral register, the closing date for receipt of nominations, the date for the opening of the poll, and the closing date for receipt of ballot papers.
10. Adjusting or revising such dates, should the Returning Officer deem fit in any particular circumstances.
11. Determining the official mark to be used for the purpose of marking ballot papers.
12. Keeping or causing to be kept appropriate records in connection with the Election.

These powers are granted to the Returning Officer under Regulation 5, which states that the Returning Officer shall have all powers necessary to carry out such functions, responsibility, and duty, and without prejudice to the generality thereof, shall have the power to make decisions with regard to the qualification or disqualification of candidates, the making of decisions in respect of valid, invalid, or spoiled votes, the conduct of counts, the transfer of votes, and all other matters which might arise during the course of the Election.

Answer:
Under the Forestry (Amendment) Regulations 2023, when an environmental impact assessment is deemed unnecessary, the following new publication and appeal procedures are introduced:

1. The Minister shall publish the determination that an environmental impact assessment is not required, together with:
   - The main reasons for not requiring such an assessment with reference to the criteria listed in Schedule 3.
   - Where proposed by the developer, any features of the project and measures envisaged to avoid or prevent what might otherwise have been significant adverse effects on the environment.

2. A determination under this regulation that an environmental impact assessment is not required may be appealed to the Forestry Appeals Committee in accordance with section 14A(4) of the Agriculture Appeals Act 2001 as part of the grounds of appeal upon which an appeal is made in respect of the licencing decision concerned.

3. An application to the High Court to review a decision in accordance with this section shall only be made where an applicant has first exercised their right to appeal a decision to the Forestry Appeals Committee in accordance with section 14A(4) of the Agriculture Appeals Act 2001.

(1) The Court may, on an application by motion on notice, strike out
Answer:
A person who purchases a dwelling on or after the commencement of these Regulations ceases to qualify as a 'relevant owner' for the scheme if they knew, or ought to have known, that defective concrete blocks were used in the construction of the dwelling at the time of purchase.

The maximum grant amount available under the Dwelling Grant Scheme is €420,000 per dwelling.

To qualify for the scheme, an applicant must submit evidence from a qualified engineer that confirms the presence of defective concrete blocks in the dwelling.

Regarding the new powers granted to the High Court under the amended Order 19 Rules 27 and 28 of the Rules of the Superior Courts:

The High Court is granted the power to strike out any claim or part of a claim, any defence or part of a defence, or any pleading or part of a pleading, if it considers such matter to be unnecessary, an abuse of the process of the Court, or if it may unreasonably prejudice or delay the fair trial of the action. The Court may also order the costs of the application to be paid as between solicitor and client if it thinks fit.

Answer:
Under the District Court (Companies Act 2014: Search Warrants) Rules 2023, when applying for a search warrant, a designated officer must provide the following information:

1. The designated officer must swear an oath stating that they are a designated officer within the meaning of section 787(13) of the Companies Act 2014, designated by the Corporate Enforcement Authority for the purposes of the said Act, and duly authorised by the said Authority.
2. The designated officer must provide reasonable grounds for suspecting that there is material information within the meaning of section 787 of the Companies Act 2014 on the premises to be searched. This includes:
   - Books or documents of which production has been required under section [state section(s) the requirement has been made under] of the Act on a specific day and which have not been produced in compliance with that requirement.
   - Books, documents, or other things (including a computer) which the designated officer has reasonable grounds for believing may provide evidence of or be related to the commission of an offence under the Act.
3. The designated officer must provide the basis for their belief that the material information is present on the premises.
4. The designated officer must apply for the issue of a search warrant under section 787 of the Companies Act 2014 in respect of the said premises.

The search warrant itself must also be issued by a Judge of the District Court, who must be satisfied that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that there is material information on the premises. The warrant must authorise the designated officer to:
- Enter the premises, if necessary by force, and search the premises.
- Require any person found on the premises to give their name, home address, and occupation.
- Produce to the officer any material information that is in the custody or possession of that person.
- Seize and retain any material information found on the premises or in the custody or possession of any person found on the premises.
- Take any other steps that appear to the designated officer to be necessary for preserving or preventing interference with material information.

Answer:
A designated officer under the search warrant form issued pursuant to section 787 of the Companies Act 2014 is conferred with the following enforcement powers:

1. To enter the premises, if necessary by force, within 30 days after the date of the warrant.
2. To search the premises for material information, including books, documents, or other things that may provide evidence of or be related to the commission of an offence under the Act.
3. To require any person found on the premises to give their name, home address, and occupation.
4. To produce to the officer any material information that is in the custody or possession of the person.
5. To seize and retain any material information found on the premises or in the custody or possession of any person found on the premises.
6. To take any other steps that appear to the designated officer to be necessary for preserving or preventing interference with material information.

These powers are authorized under section 787 of the Companies Act 2014 and are to be exercised by the designated officer, accompanied by such other persons as the officer thinks necessary, upon production of the search warrant.

9. (1) Proceedings for an offence under these Regulations in relation to an 
act committed outside the State may be taken in any place in the State and the 
offence may for all incidental purposes be treated as having been committed in 
that place. 

(2) Where a person is charged with an offence referred to in paragraph (1), 
no further proceedings in the matter (other than any remand in custody or on 
bail) may be taken except by or with the consent of the Director of Public 
Prosecutions. 

(3) In proceedings for an offence referred to in paragraph (1) - 

(a) 

(b) 

a certificate purporting to be signed by an officer of the 
Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade stating that a passport 
was issued by that Department to a person on a specified date, and 

a certificate that is signed by an officer of the Minister for Justice, 
Home Affairs and Migration and stating that, to the best of the 
officer’s knowledge and belief, the person has not ceased to be an 
Irish citizen, 

is evidence that the person was an Irish citizen on the date on which the offence 
is alleged to have been committed, and is taken to have been signed by the person 
purporting to have signed it, unless the contrary is shown. 

(4) A person who has been acquitted or convicted of an offence in a place 
outside the State shall not be proceeded against for an offence under these 
Regulations in relation to an act committed outside the State consisting of the 
conduct, or substantially the same conduct, that constituted the offence of which 
the person has been acquitted or convicted.
Answer:
To establish that the accused was an Irish citizen on the relevant date in prosecutions for offences alleged to have been committed outside the State, documentary evidence may be used in the form of:

1. A certificate purporting to be signed by an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade stating that a passport was issued by that Department to a person on a specified date.
2. A certificate signed by an officer of the Minister for Justice, Home Affairs and Migration stating that, to the best of the officer's knowledge and belief, the person has not ceased to be an Irish citizen.

These certificates are treated by the court as evidence that the person was an Irish citizen on the date on which the offence is alleged to have been committed, and are taken to have been signed by the person purporting to have signed them, unless the contrary is shown.
