EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

The Ministers and Secretaries (Amendment) (No. 2) Act, 1977, provides, inter 
alia, for the delegation of powers and duties from Ministers to Ministers of 
State by way of a Government Order. Such Orders are normally made where a 
Minister of State is expected to carry out statutory functions on behalf of a 
Minister. It should be noted that every power or duty delegated continues to be 
vested in the Minister of the Government concurrently with the Minister of 
State and may be exercised or performed by either. This Order provides for the 
delegation of functions relating to Sport Ireland by the Minister for Tourism, 
Culture, Arts, Gaeltacht, Sport and Media to the Minister of State with 
responsibility for Sport.

(This note is not part of the instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

These Regulations provide for the enforcement of restrictive measures 
contained in Council Regulation (EU) No 2015/1755 regarding restrictive 
measures concerning Burundi. 

The Regulations provide that competent authorities of the State may issue 
directions for the purpose of giving full effect to the sanctions. 

The Regulations create offences for breach of the Council Regulations or for 
failure to comply with the directions of competent authorities of the State with 
regard to implementation of the sanctions and provides for appropriate 
penalties.

(a) 

on summary conviction, to a class A fine or imprisonment

Answer:
A person convicted under these Regulations is liable to penalties as outlined in Regulation 3A. 

On summary conviction, the penalty is a class A fine or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12 months, or both. 

On conviction on indictment, the penalty is a fine not exceeding €50,000 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 years, or both.

3. The evidence that a person is to provide for the purposes of establishing 
himself or herself as an eligible family member is prescribed for the purposes of 
section 42(1)(f) and 48(2)(a)(ii) of the Act: 

(a) An applicant may provide a Director with such public records, 
including but not

or baptismal records, in order to enable the Director to satisfy

(c) Where the documents provided to a Director are, in his or her

it necessary, a Director may request the provision of an affidavit

Provisions regarding the requirements for a notification of objection referred to

Answer:
To establish themselves as an eligible family member under the Institutional Burials Act 2022, an applicant may provide the following forms of evidence:

1. Public records, including but not limited to:
   - Birth certificates
   - Marriage certificates
   - Death certificates issued under section 13 of the Civil Registration Act 2004
   These records will enable the Director to satisfy themselves that the applicant is an eligible family member.

2. Other records, including but not limited to:
   - Institutional records
   - Medical records
   - Baptismal records
   These records will enable the Director to satisfy themselves that the applicant is an eligible family member, where public records are not available or are deemed insufficient.

3. An affidavit, where the Director considers it necessary, with such information as is considered necessary by the Director to satisfy themselves that the person is an eligible family member.

4. The Director may use the powers provided under sections 27 and 29 of the Act to support the assessment of evidence provided by the applicant for the purposes of establishing themselves as an eligible family member.

It is essential to note that the Director's decision on the sufficiency of the evidence provided by the applicant will be made in accordance with the provisions of the Institutional Burials Act 2022.

or her decision to participate in an Identification Programme
Answer:
A Director must follow the procedures outlined in regulation 5 to contact eligible family members who may wish to object to participation in an Identification Programme. These procedures include:

1. Requesting contact information from another eligible family member of the same deceased person who has made a notification to the Director under section 42(1)(b) of the Act (regulation 5(2)(a)).
2. Using evidence provided by another eligible family member of the same deceased person under section 42(1)(f) of the Act (regulation 5(2)(b)).
3. Using the powers provided under sections 27 and 29 of the Act to make contact (regulation 5(2)(d)).
4. Identifying additional means by which contact information can be obtained (regulation 5(2)(d)).

If contact information is obtained, the Director must attempt to make contact with the eligible family member by means that they consider appropriate, and provide them with the following information:

* That an Identification Programme is taking place under the Act (regulation 5(3)(a)).
* That the person has a right to object to the participation of another eligible family member who has notified the Director of an interest in participating (regulation 5(3)(b)).
* That any objection will be considered in accordance with section 48(2)(b) of the Act (regulation 5(3)(c)).
* The deadline for the receipt of an objection, which may not be later than 30 days after receipt of the information provided for in this regulation (regulation 5(3)(d)).

Additionally, if an eligible family member who has made a notification to a Director under section 42(1)(b)(i) of the Act states that they are not aware of the existence of another eligible family member that would be entitled to object to the person's participation, the Director may request an affidavit or other statutory declaration to that effect (regulation 5(4)). Similarly, if an eligible family member who has made a notification to a Director under section 42(1)(b)(i) of the Act states that they are unaware of the whereabouts of another eligible family member that would be entitled to object to the person's participation, a Director may request that the person provide an affidavit or other statutory declaration to that effect (regulation 5(5)).

Finally, a Director may conclude that it is not possible to make contact with an eligible family member under section 44(4) of the Act where they have undertaken the procedures set out in this regulation and have been unable to make such contact (regulation 5(6)).

12. Where an offence under these Regulations is committed by a body

being a director, manager, secretary or other officer of the body corporate, or a

the body corporate, be guilty of an offence and shall be liable to be proceeded 
against and punished as if he or she were guilty of the first mentioned offence.

comprise a constituency and are entitled to elect 3 producer

GIVEN under my Official Seal,

CHARLIE MCCONALOGUE, 

Minister for Agriculture, Food and the Marine. 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4 [373]
Answer:
The Regulations redefine the constituencies entitled to elect producer members to the National Milk Agency by introducing two new constituencies and modifying the existing ones. 

The first constituency comprises registered producers who have supplied raw milk for heat treatment for liquid consumption to one or more of the following: Tirlán Limited, Lakeland Dairies Co-Operative Society Limited, Aurivo Co-operative Society Limited, and Glenisk Limited. These producers are entitled to elect 3 producer members to the National Milk Agency.

The second constituency comprises registered producers who have supplied raw milk for heat treatment for liquid consumption to one or more of the following: The Village Dairy Limited, Mossfield Organic Farm Ltd., Bainne Codladh Ltd., Arrabawn Co-operative Society Limited, Clona Dairy Products Society Limited, Dairygold Co-operative Society Limited (as agent for Tirlán Limited), Dawn Dairies Limited (Kerry Creameries Limited T/A Kerry Agribusiness – Dairies), Lee Strand Co-operative Creamery Limited, North Cork Co-operative Creameries Limited, and Centenary Thurles Co-operative Society Limited (Thurles Fresh Milk Limited). These producers are entitled to elect 2 producer members to the National Milk Agency.

Procedural changes have also been introduced regarding the conduct of the election. The Regulations have amended Regulation 13 by substituting "the closing date for receipt of nomination papers" for "the nomination day". This change affects the timing of the nomination process.

Additionally, Regulation 20(a) has been amended by substituting "the place and times for the counting of votes, the date ('the ballot return day') by which completed ballot papers must be received by the returning officer" for "the place and times for the counting of votes". This change affects the timing and procedures for the counting of votes.

Lastly, Regulation 28(1) has been amended by substituting "On the working day next following the ballot return day, or such other day as may be approved by the returning officer" for "At the hour of 2.00 p.m. on the day next following the day on which the return of all ballot papers issued at an election to the returning officer is completed". This change affects the timing of the declaration of the election results.

These changes aim to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the election process for producer members to the National Milk Agency.

Answer:
These Regulations introduce the following new provisions regarding the timing for receipt of nomination papers, ballot return day, and the counting of votes in National Milk Agency elections:

1. The closing date for receipt of nomination papers replaces the nomination day.
2. The ballot return day is introduced, by which completed ballot papers must be received by the returning officer.
3. The counting of votes will take place on the working day next following the ballot return day, or such other day as may be approved by the returning officer.

These changes are made by amending the National Milk Agency (Conduct of Elections) Regulations 1997 (S.I. No. 185 of 1997) as follows:

- Regulation 13 is amended to substitute "the closing date for receipt of nomination papers" for "the nomination day".
- Regulation 20(a) is amended to substitute "the place and times for the counting of votes, the date ("the ballot return day") by which completed ballot papers must be received by the returning officer" for "the place and times for the counting of votes".
- Regulation 28(1) is amended to substitute "On the working day next following the ballot return day, or such other day as may be approved by the returning officer" for "At the hour of 2.00 p.m. on the day next following the day on which the return of all ballot papers issued at an election to the returning officer is completed".

These amendments were made by the Minister for Agriculture, Food and the Marine, Charlie McConalogue, on 26 June 2024, and the notice of the making of this Statutory Instrument was published in "Iris Oifigiúil" of 12th July, 2024.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation) 

These Regulations give further effect to Directive 2012/27/EU of the European 
Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012, as amended by Directive 
(EU) 2018/2002 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 
December 2018 (“the Directive”), by establishing a new energy efficiency 
obligation scheme (EEOS) from the year 2023 for the achievement of energy 
savings required under Article 7 of the Directive. These Regulations revoke, 
other than Regulation 10, the European Union (Energy Efficiency Obligation 
Scheme) Regulations 2014 (S.I. No. 131 of 2014) which established the 
previous EEOS. 

The EEOS, established under these Regulations, places obligations and targets 
on certain energy companies (‘obligated parties’) which can be met by those 
parties achieving the required level of eligible energy savings. These 
Regulations set out which persons are obligated; how the energy savings 
targets are calculated and issued; how obligated parties can meet these targets, 
including certain sectoral sub-targets; specific requirements to be met relating 
to the calculation, measurement and verification of energy savings; and how 
any non-compliance with targets and other aspects of the Regulations, such as 
the provision of relevant information, shall be managed and the steps that may 
be taken where an obligated party fails to meet its obligations. Furthermore, 
provision is made for the appointment of the Sustainable Energy Authority of 
Ireland for the performance of certain functions of the Minister under the 
Regulations, including the making and publication of guidance on the 
operation of the EEOS.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

Currently, article 182 of the Social Welfare (Consolidated Claims, Payments and 
Control) Regulations 2007, provides that the prescribed time for making a claim 
for State Pension (Contributory) is within the period of 3 months before and 3 
months after that person becomes entitled to State Pension (Contributory). 

Failure to make a claim for State Pension (Contributory) within the prescribed 
time means that section 241(2) of the Social Welfare Act 2007 applies. This 
provides that where a person fails to claim within the time prescribed, that person 
will not be paid in respect of any period more than 6 months before the claim is 
made. 

These Regulations amend the prescribed time for making a claim for State 
Pension (Contributory) so that a claim may be made up to 6 months before the 
date the person becomes entitled to State Pension (Contributory). 

From end October 2024, an online application form for state pension 
(contributory) and state pension (non-contributory) will be available to 
claimants. To align state pension (contributory) application timelines with the 
state pension (non-contributory), it is necessary to increase the prescribed time 
for state pension (contributory) from 3 to 6 months. 

The prescribed period after which a person becomes entitled to State Pension 
(Contributory) in which to make a claim remains at 3 months.

Answer:
These Regulations make the following amendments to Article 182 of the Principal Regulations concerning the prescribed time for making claims to State pensions:

- The prescribed time for making a claim for State Pension (Contributory) is increased from 3 months before and 3 months after the person becomes entitled to State Pension (Contributory) to 6 months before the date the person becomes entitled to State Pension (Contributory).
- The prescribed period after which a person becomes entitled to State Pension (Contributory) in which to make a claim remains at 3 months.

These changes aim to align the application timelines for State Pension (Contributory) with those for State Pension (Non-Contributory), with the introduction of an online application form for both pensions from end October 2024.

for State Pension (Contributory) is within the period of 3 months before and 3 
months after that person becomes entitled to State Pension (Contributory).

time means that section 241(2) of the Social Welfare Act 2007 applies. This 
provides that where a person fails to claim within the time prescribed, that person 
will not be paid in respect of any period more than 6 months before the claim is

These Regulations amend the prescribed time for making a claim for State

date the person becomes entitled to State Pension (Contributory). 

From end October 2024, an online application form for state pension 
(contributory) and state pension (non-contributory) will be available to 
claimants. To align state pension (contributory) application timelines with the 
state pension (non-contributory), it is necessary to increase the prescribed time

Answer:
According to the explanatory note, these Regulations alter the prescribed time limits for claiming the State Pension (Contributory) by extending the period in which a claim may be made from 3 months before and 3 months after becoming entitled to the pension, to 6 months before the date the person becomes entitled to State Pension (Contributory).

The rationale for the change is to align the application timelines for State Pension (Contributory) with those for State Pension (Non-Contributory), as an online application form for both pensions will be available from end October 2024. This change allows claimants to make a claim up to 6 months before the date they become entitled to State Pension (Contributory), while the prescribed period after becoming entitled to make a claim remains at 3 months.

1. This Order may be cited as the Screening of Third Country Transactions 

Act 2023 (Commencement) Order 2024.
Answer:
A person who purchases a dwelling on or after the commencement of these Regulations ceases to qualify as a 'relevant owner' for the scheme if they knew, or ought to have known, that defective concrete blocks were used in the construction of the dwelling at the time of purchase.

The maximum grant amount available under the Dwelling Grant Scheme is €420,000 per dwelling.

To qualify for the scheme, an applicant must submit evidence from a qualified engineer that confirms the presence of defective concrete blocks in the dwelling.

Now, addressing the question provided:

The Screening of Third Country Transactions Act 2023 (No. 28 of 2023) comes into operation on the 6th day of January 2025. This commencement date is specified in the Statutory Instrument. The Minister of State at the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment, Dara Calleary, issues the Order bringing it into effect.

Answer:
To address the question of how statutory references to the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment and to the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment should be construed after this Order takes effect, we must consider the relevant passages.

Firstly, passage 7 states that references to the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment contained in the memorandum and articles of association of any company and relating to any function transferred by this Order shall, on and after the commencement of this Order, be construed as references to the Minister for Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science.

However, passage 4(a) of the 2020 Statutory Instrument states that references to the Department of Business, Enterprise and Innovation shall be construed as references to the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment. 

Passage 4(b) of the 2020 Statutory Instrument states that references to the Minister for Business, Enterprise and Innovation shall be construed as references to the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment.

Passage 4 of the 2025 Statutory Instrument states that references to the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment and to the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment shall be construed as references to the Department of Enterprise, Tourism and Employment and the Minister for Enterprise, Tourism and Employment, respectively.

Considering these passages, the correct interpretation is that statutory references to the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment and to the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment should be construed as follows:

- References to the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment shall be construed as references to the Department of Enterprise, Tourism and Employment, as per passage 4 of the 2025 Statutory Instrument.
- References to the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment contained in the memorandum and articles of association of any company and relating to any function transferred by this Order shall, on and after the commencement of this Order, be construed as references to the Minister for Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science, as per passage 7.
- In all other cases, references to the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment shall be construed as references to the Minister for Enterprise, Tourism and Employment, as per passage 4 of the 2025 Statutory Instrument.

Therefore, the correct answer is that statutory references to the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment and to the Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment should be construed as follows, depending on the context:

- Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment: Department of Enterprise, Tourism and Employment
- Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (in the context of company memorandum and articles of association and functions transferred by this Order): Minister for Further and Higher Education, Research, Innovation and Science
- Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (in all other cases): Minister for Enterprise, Tourism and Employment

4. (1) The Council shall appoint persons of competence and integrity to act 
as a Returning Officer and a substitute returning officer, who shall act in the 
event that the Returning Officer is unable or unavailable to act, for the purpose 
of each Election. 

(2) In this bye-law, any reference to the Returning Officer in relation to any 
act, matter or function for which a Returning Officer is appointed by or under 
this bye-law shall, unless the context otherwise requires, be interpreted as 
including a reference to the substitute returning officer. 

(3) The Returning Officer will ensure, insofar as it is possible, that neither 
he or she, nor any person employed by him or her, has any conflict of interest, 
and will avoid any perceived conflict of interest, in relation to the running of the 
Election. Should a conflict of interest arise, in relation to the Returning Officer, 
he or she will immediately notify the Council and the substitute Returning 
Officer will take over the running of the Election. In the case of a conflict arising 

 
 
 
 4 [366] 

with an employee, the Returning Officer will discontinue that employee’s 
involvement in the Election. 

(4) The Council and/or the Registration Board shall provide the Returning 
Officer with all information which the Returning Officer deems necessary for 
the purposes of conducting the Election. 

(5) The Returning Officer may, if he or she considers it necessary for the 
performance of his or her duties, and with the consent of the Council, appoint 
such person or persons as he or she considers fit and proper to assist him or her. 

(6) The Returning Officer or any person appointed by him or her for any 
purpose relating to the Election shall not be a Candidate or a Relative of a 
Candidate at that Election or associated in furthering the candidature of any 
Candidate at that Election. 

(7) The Returning Officer shall not appoint for any purpose relating to the 

Election a person who to the knowledge of the Returning Officer – 

(a) 

is or has been a Candidate, 

(b) has been associated in furthering the candidature of a Candidate, 

or 

(c) 

is a Relative of a Candidate at that Election. 

(8) The Council shall defray the reasonable expenses of a Returning Officer 

in conducting an Election. 

Powers and functions of Returning Officer
Answer:
Under this bye-law, the conflict-of-interest safeguards that apply to the Returning Officer and scrutineers during the conduct of elections to the Social Care Workers Registration Board are as follows:

- The Returning Officer must ensure that neither they nor any person employed by them has any conflict of interest, and will avoid any perceived conflict of interest (Section 3).
- If a conflict of interest arises with the Returning Officer, they must immediately notify the Council and the substitute Returning Officer will take over the running of the Election (Section 3).
- If a conflict of interest arises with an employee, the Returning Officer will discontinue that employee's involvement in the Election (Section 3).
- The Returning Officer shall not appoint a person who is or has been a Candidate, has been associated in furthering the candidature of a Candidate, or is a Relative of a Candidate at that Election for any purpose relating to the Election (Section 7).
- The Returning Officer or any person appointed by them for any purpose relating to the Election shall not be a Candidate or a Relative of a Candidate at that Election or associated in furthering the candidature of any Candidate at that Election (Section 6).
- The Returning Officer shall not appoint a person who is a Relative of a Candidate at that Election for any purpose relating to the Election (Section 7).

These safeguards aim to prevent conflicts of interest and ensure the integrity of the election process.

Answer:
An election may be postponed, rescheduled, or restarted by the Returning Officer under the following conditions:

1. An emergency or special difficulty arises, as determined by the Returning Officer.
2. The Returning Officer deems it necessary or desirable to make changes or modifications to the procedures for the conduct of the Election.
3. The error in the conduct of the Election is fundamental, as regarded by the Returning Officer.

In such cases, the Returning Officer may:

1. Reschedule, postpone, or curtail the applicable times.
2. Suspend the application of all or any part of the procedures.
3. Recommemce the Election (or any part thereof) from the point prior to the point when the error arose.
4. Take such action as may be necessary or desirable to enable the declaration of persons elected.

The Returning Officer is obligated to publish summary details of any such emergency, error, or special difficulty, and the changes or modifications made to the procedures, insofar as the circumstances permit.

This obligation is consistent across all the provided passages, which outline the Returning Officer's powers and responsibilities in the event of an emergency or special difficulty.

Answer:
Based on the provided passages, the amendments made to the District Court (Areas) Order 1961 concerning the days and times of court sittings in Nenagh and Thurles under this Order are as follows:

- For Nenagh:
  - The original passage is not provided, but the subsequent passages show that the amendments made to the days and times of court sittings in Nenagh are as follows:
    - Fourth Monday in each month.
    - First, Second, Third, and Fourth Thursday in each month.
    - First, Second, and Third Friday in each month.
    - All sittings at 10.30 a.m.

- For Thurles:
  - The original passage is not provided, but the subsequent passages show that the amendments made to the days and times of court sittings in Thurles are as follows:
    - First, Second, Third, and Fourth Tuesday in each month.
    - Third Wednesday in each month.
    - All sittings at 10.30 a.m.

However, in the last passage, it is mentioned that the Second Schedule to the District Court (Areas) Order, 1961 (S.I. No. 5 of 1961) is hereby amended by the substitution at reference number 201 for the matter in column (4) of the following:

“Nenagh — Fourth Monday in each month. First, Second, Third and Fourth Thursday in each month. First, Second, and Third Friday in each month. All sittings at 10.30 a.m.”

and the substitution at reference number 204 for the matter in column (4) of the following:

“Thurles — First, Second, Third and Fourth Tuesday in each month. Third Wednesday in each month. All sittings at 10.30 a.m.”

Therefore, the final amendments made to the District Court (Areas) Order 1961 concerning the days and times of court sittings in Nenagh and Thurles under this Order are:

- For Nenagh:

  - First, Second, Third, and Fourth Thursday in each month.
  - First, Second, and Third Friday in each month.
  - All sittings at 10.30 a.m.

- For Thurles:
  - First, Second, Third, and Fourth Tuesday in each month.
  - Third Wednesday in each month.
  - All sittings at 10.30 a.m.

in Regulation 4 –

“(10) Subject to paragraphs 12A, 16 and 17 of the First Schedule,

Answer:
These Regulations introduce a new provision concerning eligible vehicles, specifically those that emit no CO2 tailpipe emissions. 

The new provision allows eligible vehicles to display a registration plate with a green stripe. This provision is introduced by the insertion of a new paragraph after Regulation 9(9) in the Vehicle Registration and Taxation Regulations, 1992 (S.I. No. 318 of 1992). 

The specific regulation that introduces this new provision is Regulation 4(c), which states that an eligible vehicle may display a plate which contains a stripe which is green in colour, subject to paragraphs 12A, 16, and 17 of the First Schedule.

Answer:
According to the First Schedule amendments, the specifications governing the green stripe and character dimensions on eligible vehicle registration plates are as follows:

- The green stripe for an eligible vehicle shall be colour Pantone 7481c or a colour match that is as close as possible to this colour and shall be formed of reflex reflective material (paragraph 12A).
- The identification mark shall appear in black characters, and each letter or figure shall have a height of not less than 65 millimetres and not more than 70 millimetres (paragraph 14).
- The stroke width of each letter or figure shall be not less than 9 millimetres and not more than 10 millimetres (paragraph 14).
- The total width of the space taken by each letter or figure (other than the letter “I” or the number “1”) shall be not less than 33 millimetres and not more than 50 millimetres (paragraph 14).
- The distances between adjoining figures shall be uniform and shall be not less than 8 millimetres (paragraph 14).
- The green stripe for an eligible vehicle shall extend vertically from the inner edge of the black border at the top of the plate to the inner edge of the black border at the bottom of the plate and shall extend horizontally for a distance of 30 millimetres from the inner edge of the black border on the right-hand side of the plate (paragraph 16(h)).
- The green stripe for an eligible vehicle shall extend vertically from the lower edge of the blue background of the flag of the European Communities to the inner edge of the black border at the bottom of the plate and shall extend horizontally for a distance of 45 millimetres from the inner edge of the black border on the left-hand side of the plate (paragraph 17(l)).

Answer:
The Employment Equality Act 1998 (Section 20A) (Gender Pay Gap Information) (Amendment) Regulations 2025 modify the definition of 'relevant employer' and the timeline for reporting obligations as follows:

The definition of 'relevant employer' is modified by substituting "50" for "150" in Regulation 2. This means that the Regulations now apply to employers with 50 or more employees, rather than 150 or more employees.

The timeline for reporting obligations is modified by substituting "5 months" for "6 months" in Regulation 6(1). This means that employers with 50 or more employees must now report their gender pay gap information within 5 months of the end of the relevant reporting period, rather than 6 months.

These modifications were made by the Employment Equality Act 1998 (Section 20A) (Gender Pay Gap Information) (Amendment) Regulations 2025, which were signed into law by Minister Norma Foley on 27 May 2025.

Answer:
A person who purchases a dwelling on or after the commencement of these Regulations ceases to qualify as a 'relevant owner' for the scheme if they knew, or ought to have known, that defective concrete blocks were used in the construction of the dwelling at the time of purchase.

The maximum grant amount available under the Dwelling Grant Scheme is €420,000 per dwelling.

To qualify for the scheme, an applicant must submit evidence from a qualified engineer that confirms the presence of defective concrete blocks in the dwelling.

Regarding your question, Regulation 2 declares each of the substances, products, and preparations specified in the Schedule to be a controlled drug for the purposes of the Misuse of Drugs Act 1977 (No. 12 of 1977). This means that Regulation 2 has the legal effect of controlling the substances listed in the Schedule under the Misuse of Drugs Act 1977.

8. (1) Proceedings for an offence under these Regulations in relation to an 
act committed outside the State may be taken in any place in the State and the 
offence may for all incidental purposes be treated as having been committed in 
that place. 

(2) Where a person is charged with an offence referred to in paragraph (1), 
no further proceedings in the matter (other than any remand in custody or on 
bail) may be taken except by or with the consent of the Director of Public 
Prosecutions. 

(3) In proceedings for an offence referred to in paragraph (1), 

(a) 

(b) 

a certificate purporting to be signed by an officer of the 
Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and stating that a 
passport was issued by that Department to a person on a 
specified date, and 

a certificate that is signed by an officer of the Minister for 
Justice and Equality and stating that, to the best of the officer’s 
knowledge and belief, the person has not ceased to be an Irish 
citizen, 

is evidence that the person was an Irish citizen on the date on which the 
offence is alleged to have been committed, and is taken to have been signed by 
the person purporting to have signed it, unless the contrary is shown. 

(4) A person who has been acquitted or convicted of an offence in a place 
outside the State shall not be proceeded against for an offence under these 
Regulations in relation to an act committed outside the State consisting of the 
conduct, or substantially the same conduct, that constituted the offence of 
which the person has been acquitted or convicted.
Answer:
For offences relating to acts committed outside the State, the following procedural prerequisites apply:

1. Proceedings for an offence under these Regulations may be taken in any place in the State, and the offence may be treated as having been committed in that place (Regulation 8(1)).
2. No further proceedings in the matter (other than any remand in custody or on bail) may be taken except by or with the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions (Regulation 8(2)).

The documentary evidence admissible to prove Irish citizenship of the accused includes:

1. A certificate purporting to be signed by an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, stating that a passport was issued by that Department to a person on a specified date (Regulation 8(3)(a)).
2. A certificate signed by an officer of the Minister for Justice and Equality, stating that, to the best of the officer's knowledge and belief, the person has not ceased to be an Irish citizen (Regulation 8(3)(b)).

These certificates are taken to be evidence that the person was an Irish citizen on the date on which the offence is alleged to have been committed, unless the contrary is shown (Regulation 8(3)).

Answer:
The definition of "plan" in the 2011 Regulations is amended by these Regulations to include planning instruments under the 2000 and 2024 Planning Acts. Specifically, the definition of "plan" is updated to refer to:

- A land use plan within the meaning of the Planning and Development Act 2000 (No. 30 of 2000)
- A plan within the meaning of section 198 of the Planning and Development Act 2024 (No. 34 of 2024)

This amendment replaces the previous definition of "plan" as "land use plan within the meaning of the Planning Acts 2000 to 2011".

RetrievedPassages:
EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

These Regulations provide for a consequential amendment to the European 
Communities (Birds and Natural Habitats) Regulations 2011 (S.I. No. 477/2011) 
(“the 2011 Regulations”) arising from the commencement of Chapter 2 of Part 
6 of the Planning and Development Act 2024 (“Act of 2024”). Under Regulation 
2(1) of the 2011 Regulations, ‘land use plans’ within the meaning of the Planning 
and Development Act 2000 are not within the scope, except where the contrary 
intention appears, of the definition of ‘plan’ for the purposes of the 2011 
Regulations. These Regulations extend this exclusion from scope to also include 
“plans” within the meaning of section 198 of the Act of 2024. This amendment 
is on the basis that such plans (e.g. regional spatial and economic strategies, 
development plans) will be subject to appropriate assessment requirements 
under Chapter 2 of Part 6 of the Act of 2024 and therefore should not be within 
scope of the appropriate assessment requirements that apply to plans under the 
2011 Regulations (except where the contrary intention appears).
